name: Kepler-205
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-205 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-205 is a star with 0.4499999999999998 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.55 times its radius. It is located 523.35 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-205 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-205 b

Kepler-205 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.76 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-205.

The mass of Kepler-205 b is 2.60 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-205 b is 1.51 that of Earth. At 2.60 Earth masses, Kepler-205 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-205 c

Kepler-205 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 20.31 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-205.

The mass of Kepler-205 c is 3.14 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-205 c is 1.64 that of Earth. At 3.14 Earth masses, Kepler-205 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-205, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
